If a person is about to die, their breath becomes coarse, their throat and tongue dry, unable to swallow water, their speech is unclear, their gaze is not proper, their muscles and veins are severed, the wind of a knife cuts their body, their limbs and joints relax, the mechanism stops and they cannot move, their whole body aches as if being pricked by needles.

When their life ends, they see great darkness as if falling into a deep pit, wandering alone in the wilderness without companions. Only the merit they have cultivated becomes their close friend and protector.
If it is for the next world, one should quickly cultivate merit.
Then he spoke a verse, saying:
When a person's life ends, they go alone without companions,
They will definitely abandon their beloved relatives and friends,
Wandering alone in the dark, a frightening and terrifying place,
All loved ones will part ways, and one will be lonely and friendless.
Therefore, one should adorn oneself with the provisions of wholesome dharmas.
In order to fulfill this meaning, VÄrÄhadeva praised the king with six verses, saying:
Although one may have various precious treasures accumulated like the Himalayas,

And should cultivate various wholesome actions in order to gain benefit and happiness for oneself.
One whose eyes are like blue lotuses should diligently practice precepts and giving,
Death is a great fear, and those who hear of it are all terrified.
In all the worlds, there is no one who does not eventually perish,

In order to obtain one's own benefit and happiness, one should diligently practice precepts and giving.

In order to obtain one's own benefit and happiness, one should diligently practice precepts and giving.
Milik-na-hou-sha, Ya-ya-ti the great king,
And Tunduma-ra, Sagha-ti-pu,
Kio-li-sha-shi-fu, Yu-ch'ieh-p'ing-shih-po,
Such supreme people among men, the victorious great kings and others,

Joy and sorrow arise in succession, and thoughts arise in sequence.
One whose eyes are like blue lotuses should cultivate good deeds,
Causing oneself to experience happiness, one should diligently practice precepts and giving.
Wealth, treasures, and glory and nobility, these things are difficult to encounter,
Merit and rank are not always present, and physical strength has its ups and downs.
Everything has no fixed characteristics, and the lord of the land is also not permanent,
Such things are most difficult, and now I have fully obtained them.
One with eyes like blue lotuses should fully cultivate all that is good,
Causing oneself to experience happiness, one should diligently cultivate precepts and giving.
Those who are vigorous, brave, and powerful are able to cross the great ocean,
Those who single-mindedly remember and are vigorous are able to transcend all mountains.
Even if one accomplishes such things, it is not yet considered difficult,
Being able to benefit future lives, this is the difficult thing.
Furthermore, this body is not solid, therefore the wise should distinguish and make offerings to elders, this is called using impermanent things to exchange for permanent things.

The Yasha felt ashamed and returned to the king, joined his palms together, and spoke a verse, saying:

all of them got a price, and people competed to buy them.
All the heads had a use, only the human head was filthy and evil,ğŸ”½there was not a single use for it, given away for free no one was willing to take it,
and they scolded me instead, let alone anyone who would buy it.

If this head, whether noble or lowly, is equally despised, why do you now, relying on your own noble lineage, color, and wisdom, want to stop me from paying homage to the ÅšÄkya sons, the Å›ramaá¹‡as?
Then he spoke a verse, saying:

Although bowing to it, there is not the slightest harm.
The king said to YaÅ›as,
Mixed lineage and lowly, unable to see its inner,
True possession of morality and virtue.
Deluded and confused, the mind reckons itself a brahmin,
Only those with the factors of liberation, the rest of the various lineages,
Have no one who attains liberation.
If one wishes to have a marriage,
One should seek a good family;
If one seeks good dharmas, what use is a good family?

If one commits extremely evil deeds, all people will scold and rebuke,
This is then called low and humble.

This is then called noble and distinguished.
Since one's virtues and practices are already full, why not pay homage and respect?
If one's mind is good, one's body will be noble. Åšramaá¹‡as cultivate all that is good,
Faith, precepts, giving, and learning are complete, therefore one is worthy of respect,
One should deeply revere and honor them.
Have you not heard that the ÅšÄkya clan possesses great compassion,
The bull among men, the one on the right path, has expounded the Dharma?
Using these three fragile dharmas to trade for the three firm dharmas,
The Buddha has no different words, so I dare not disobey,
If I disobey the World-Honored One's teachings, I cannot be called a close friend.
It is like pressing sugarcane to take the juice and discarding the dregs,
The human body is also like this, being pressed by death.
The corpse is left on the ground, unable to move again,
Making offerings, respecting, and cultivating various wholesome deeds, therefore one should know this.
Using this decaying body to trade for the firm and solid dharma,
It is like when a house is on fire, the wise one takes out their wealth,
Like water submerging a hidden treasure, one should also quickly take out the jewels,
This body will eventually decay, so one should trade it for the firm and solid dharma.
The foolish do not discriminate between the firm and the unfirm dharmas,
The army of death suddenly arrives, like entering the mouth of a makaras,
At such a time, one will be frightened and greatly terrified.
Just as when taking fresh butter from curd, and then taking ghee,
After taking it, the curd pot is broken, but one does not give rise to great distress.
This body is also like this. Taking its firm and solid goodness,
At the end of one's life, one will never give rise to regret.
Not cultivating any wholesome practices, arrogant and unrestrained,
The law of death suddenly arrives, breaking the vessel of the body,
One's mind becomes extremely agitated, as if being burned by fire.
Sorrow and affliction are likened to fire. The curd pot is likened to the body.
You should not obstruct me from cultivating goodness and taking firm dharmas.
The foolish and dark ones say, I am noble.
I, the one who holds the ten powers, the lamp of speech,
Illuminate and examine within my own body, noble and humble without distinction,
Skin, flesh, sinews, bones, and so forth, thirty-six kinds of substances,
Noble and lowly are all the same, what differences are there?
Name-robes and upper garments, various implements have distinctions.
The wise should diligently make respectful prostrations,
Employing them to do good, this is called taking the firm Dharma.
Why is this said?
This body is like lightning, fleeting, like a foam or a pile of sand, like a plantain with no solid core.
Such a fragile body, cultivating goodness for a hundred eons,
Is firmer than Mount Sumeru, and the great earth.
The wise should be like this, trading for the firm and real Dharma.
Furthermore, if those who argue hear the name of severing afflictions, the disputed matter will be resolved. If a person wishes to obtain offerings and respect, they should sever all afflictions.
I once heard that there was an old woman who entered the forest to pick betel leaves to sell for a living. She passed through a checkpoint, and the guards demanded taxes from her.
At that time, the old woman did not want to pay taxes, and said to them:
If you can take me to the king, you may collect the tax. If not, I will never give it to you.
Then the guards argued and went to the king. The king asked the old woman:
Why do you not pay the checkpoint tax now?
The old woman said to the king:
Does the king know that monk so-and-so?
The king said:
I know him, he is a great arhat.
He asked again:
Does the king recognize the second monk?
The king said:
I recognize him, he is also an arhat.
He asked again:
Does the king recognize the third monk?
The king replied:
I recognize him, he is also an arhat.
The old woman raised her voice and said to the king:
These three arhats are all my sons. These sons of mine receive the king's offerings and can cause the great king to receive immeasurable blessings. This is called giving the king his due.
How can you want to tax and deprive me again?
When the king heard this, he marveled at it.
Excellent, old woman!
I truly did not know that you could give birth to holy sons.
Knowing that those arhats are your sons, I should make offerings to you and respect you.
Then the old woman spoke a verse, saying:
I gave birth to three sons, courageous and strong, surpassing the three realms,
All of them attained arhatship and became fields of merit for the world.
When the king makes offerings, he obtains blessings by taxing goods,
How can he use expedient means to tax and take away all that I have?
When the king heard these verses, his body hair stood on end. He gave rise to a mind of faith and respect towards the Three Jewels and said with tears flowing:
Such an old mother should be given offerings, let alone have her goods taxed?
The king spoke a verse, saying:
From now on, for such old mothers,
Those who have given birth to children and crossed the three realms are vessels worthy of receiving offerings.
Their goods should not be taxed, and they should all be treated with respect.
Even if they have companions, camels, donkeys, and carts,
Loaded with many precious treasures, for the sake of this old mother,
They should not be taxed.
If a single person sells tree leaves and has no other money or goods,
Should they still be taxed and taken away?
At the places where practitioners walk and cultivate the path,
Even if one has not yet eliminated afflictions and severed all outflows, one should still revere those places,
Respect them, and make offerings.
How much more so for this elderly mother who gave birth to a sage - how could one not cultivate respect?

(18) Once I heard that there was a son of a great merchant named Åšroá¹‡akoá¹­Ä«viá¹ƒÅ›a who went to sea to collect treasures, returned safely, stayed separately from his companions, lost his companions, and was confused and tormented by hunger and thirst.
He saw a city in the distance and thought there was water. He went to the edge of the city, wanting to ask for water to drink.

However, this city was a city of hungry ghosts. When he arrived in the middle of the city, at the head of the four-way intersection where people gathered, he saw nothing. Tormented by hunger and thirst, he cried out, Water! Water!
The hungry ghosts all came and gathered, hearing the sound of water.
Who is the compassionate one who wants to give us water?
These hungry ghosts, with bodies like charred pillars and hair covering themselves, all came together, put their palms together, and said:
Please give us water.
EkaÅ›á¹›á¹…ga said:
I am thirsty and come here to seek water.
At that time, the hungry ghosts heard that EkaÅ›á¹›á¹…ga was thirsty and came himself to seek water, and all hope was lost. They all sighed and said:
Do you not know that this is the city of hungry ghosts? How can you seek water here?
Then they spoke a verse, saying:
We dwell in this city, for hundreds of thousands of years,
We have never even heard the name of water, let alone getting to drink it.
It is like a tÄla forest, burning fiercely in a fire,
We are also like this, with all our limbs on fire.
The hair is all disheveled, and the body is all ruined,
Day and night thinking of food and drink, wandering and running in the ten directions.
Afflicted by hunger and thirst, they open their mouths and run about seeking,
But someone wielding a staff follows behind, chasing after them and beating them.
The ears always hear evil sounds, never a kind word,
Let alone a single drop of water to moisten my throat and tongue.
If in the mountains and valleys, heavenly dragons bring down sweet dew,
It all turns into boiling fire and pours down on my body.ğŸ”½If seeing the various canals and rivers, they all turn into flowing fire,
The ponds, marshes, rivers, and springs are all seen to be dried up,
Or they turn into thick blood, foul-smelling and extremely disgusting.
If wanting to run towards them, the yakshas seize iron hammers,
Beating them so they cannot get close.
We experience this suffering, how can we obtain water to use to give to you?
In our previous lives, we were extremely stingy, greedy, and jealous,
Never giving to a single person, water and food.
Not giving one's own possessions to others, and preventing others from giving,
Because of these grave karmic offenses, one now experiences this suffering.
Giving brings great rewards. In spring one plants seeds and in autumn one harvests the fruits.
We did not plant seeds, and today we experience this suffering.
Careless, stingy, and greedy, one experiences this suffering without end.
There is no seed of suffering that surpasses greed and jealousy.
One should diligently apply skillful means to remove such afflictions.
Giving is the seed of goodness, able to produce all benefits and joy.
Therefore, one should cultivate giving, not like us experiencing suffering.
All are the same in the human realm, with no difference in physical form,
Yet the created karma is not the same, and the experienced retribution is also different.
The wealthy and noble with abundant wealth and treasures, the poor come to request,
The gods eat from the same vessel, but the color of the rice is different for each.
If one falls into the animal realm, the karmic retribution is also not the same,
Some attain the enjoyment of blessings, while others experience suffering and distress.
Because of this poison of greed, humans, gods, and animals,
Are agitated by stinginess and jealousy, and wherever they are, they are diminished.
The suffering of hungry ghosts is blazing, with smoke and flames rising from their limbs,
Like the red flowers on a tree, a drunken elephant with its trunk tip,
Throws them far into the sky, and the flowers fall down, staining its body red.
The sages say that stinginess and jealousy are the most painful vessels,
When seeing a beggar, their mind becomes agitated and turbid,
In that moment of agitation and turbidity, they are able to create contemptible defilements.
Foolishly stingy and not giving, they plant the roots of poverty,
With a greedy mind they accumulate, and then fall into the evil paths,
Thus, stinginess and greed are the root of all suffering and distress.
Therefore, the wise should eliminate stinginess and greed.ğŸ”½Who would abandon the right path and follow crooked and evil paths,
If they wish for self-enjoyment, fame, respect, and so forth?
In this life, one will experience suffering and distress, and in the next life, it will be the same.
Karmic afflictions in the world can obstruct the rewards of pure giving,
Namely, this stinginess and greed are the greatest among all enemies.
This body is greatly swollen, and clothing, food, medicine,
And all kinds of pleasures are obstructed by greed and jealousy.
Greed and jealousy are extremely subtle, and it is difficult to prevent them from entering the mind.
One should use the firm gate of giving to make the house of the mind tightly sealed.
Do not allow greed and jealousy to enter it.
If greed and jealousy enter the mind, it is like a river or the great ocean.
able to stop them from drinking.
There are such faults, then one detests birth and death,
returning to seek to leave the household life.ğŸ”½Having left the household life, diligently cultivating concentration and wisdom,
attaining the fruit of arhatship.
(19) Furthermore, if one who is without fault scolds others, if one who has faults scolds them, others will laugh in return.
I once heard, a naked brahman was traveling with some monks.
There was a young monk who laughed at the naked one, saying he had no shame.
At that time, among the naked ones there was a brahman who had a little understanding of the Buddha's teachings. He said to the monk:
Elder!

You cannot use your renunciant insignia to slight and deceive others, you cannot use your renunciant appearance to cut off afflictions. If you are not yet able to cut them off, you will continue to transmigrate in birth and death without a time to escape. In your next life you will not be free from being naked. Why do you laugh at him?
You are like a cotton tree flower in the midst of birth and death, following the wind to the east and west without a fixed time. You should laugh at yourself and not laugh at others.
Knowing where you will go in the future,
Like ashes covering fire, with afflictions in the mind, it cannot be guaranteed.
Do not think of yourself as having shame and conscience, seeing what you have done, you have not yet escaped from the net of views.
Those with shame and conscience definitely do not enter the net of views. If one does not give rise to evil thoughts, this is called shame and conscience.
You yourself are not in the ranks of certainty, so how can you laugh at others?
At that time, the bhiká¹£us heard the naked brÄhmaá¹‡a speak in accordance with the Dharma, but remained silent without replying.

(20) Furthermore, one who observes well sees no desire in beautiful colors and often gives rise to disgust. When seeing beautiful colors, one does not give rise to love or hatred.
I once heard that there was a temple with many bhiká¹£us.

There was a Dharma master there, with the three knowledges and six supernormal powers, whose words were skillful and wonderful, who was fully endowed with eloquence, who knew the theories of self and others and was able to ask and answer, who spoke the Dharma according to the capacities of the audience and delighted the minds of the people, who was able to light the lamp of the Dharma to illuminate and remove the darkness of ignorance, causing the people inside and outside the city to come and listen to the Dharma day after day, and after listening and receiving it, even the young ones were not negligent.
At that time, there was an old prostitute in the city who sighed and said like this:
Now that no one comes and goes, we will suffer like this for a long time?
That prostitute's daughter was in her prime, upright, intelligent, and extraordinary, skilled in worldly theories. She was well-versed in all sixty-four skills of a woman.
Seeing her mother's sorrowful expression, she asked her mother, saying:
Why are you so sorrowful now?
Her mother told her, saying:
All the people in this city enjoy listening to the Dharma. No one comes to me anymore, and my wealth and possessions are exhausted. This is why I am sad.
When the girl heard this, she boasted of her own beauty and said to her mother, I will now adorn myself and go to that assembly. I can make all the people in that assembly follow me.

Having said this, she bathed herself, applied fragrant oils to her body, put on jeweled necklaces and upper garments, wore a flower garland on her head, put on shoes adorned with various treasures, held a staff in her right hand, walked with a coquettish gait, swayed her body in various ways, and adorned herself in many ways, like a walking flower tree. She was like a celestial being, with attendants, flower garlands, jeweled necklaces, and beautifully adorned upper garments.
These attendants either held golden vases, carried whisks and fans, or held incense and flowers, serving the girl.

Surrounded by the entertainers, they spoke and laughed, sometimes raising their right index finger to point out the way. Some had yellow robes with various flowers inserted, and their bodies were painted with various colors such as yellow, red, and purple. They joyfully laughed and playfully teased in various ways, also raising their index fingers to point to the front and back. Along the road, the fragrance permeated everywhere, and they went to the temple in a carriage, to an empty room, waiting for the assembly to gather.
When it was time for the Dharma talk, countless thousands of people all came and gathered.

At that time, the Dharma teacher had extremely white hair and bushy eyebrows covering his eyes. He skillfully controlled his faculties and his mind was fearless, like a lion king. He then ascended the high seat and spoke a verse, saying:
I observe those with shallow wisdom, unable to ascend this seat,
timid and weak like a wild fox, trembling with fear and unable to be at ease.
I now ascend this seat, being in the assembly without fear,
like the king among beasts, roaring and destroying heretical theories.
At that time, the Dharma teacher then spoke the Dharma in sequence for the great assembly.

At that time, the prostitute, in order to disturb the minds of the assembly, immediately revealed her body in the doorway. Her attendants scattered into the human realm, each pointing to the prostitute and saying to the people:
This woman is upright, beautiful, and lovely. You should all look at her. What is the use of listening to the Dharma?
At that time, those people, having heard these words, immediately looked back, their minds and thoughts uneasy.
At that time, the Dharma teacher did not understand their intention and wondered why. He then asked the people:
Why do you look so different, your minds and thoughts in disarray?
Do you not know that death comes swiftly, like a galloping horse? Therefore, you should diligently cultivate all wholesome practices.
He then spoke a verse, saying:
The great Dharma torch of the Ten Powers universally illuminates the world.
The light of wisdom has not yet been hidden. You should quickly cultivate wholesome karma.
Firmly intent, accumulate wholesome conduct, day and night, do not be lax,
The lamp of the speech of omniscience will soon be extinguished.
If after its extinction, beings are completely in darkness,
Although there is the illumination of sunlight, it is still called great darkness.
At that time, the assembly, having heard these verses, respectfully accepted the Dharma teachings and focused their minds to listen to the Dharma.

At that time, the courtesan, seeing that the assembly had focused their minds and intentions, again made seductive gestures. The assembly, having seen this, their minds became scattered and agitated again.
At that time, the Dharma teacher again spoke a verse, saying:
That woman makes seductive gestures, causing the assembly to give rise to craving,
Because of being pulled by lustful thoughts, she steals their focused minds.
In order to respectfully follow my teachings, I restrain and stop her,
How can that deceitful woman confuse and agitate the eyes of the assembly?
It is like a garland of blue lotuses, floating and moving with the waves,
Shining and sparkling, not staying still for a moment.
At that time, the people's minds were already addicted and deluded. Seeing this wonderful form, they lost their sense of shame. They pointed at each other and spoke a verse, saying:
This woman's beautiful appearance, now coming, is very auspicious,
Like that newly born moon, falling down on the ground,

Then another person spoke a verse, saying:

Both cheeks are completely full, her red lips and teeth are evenly close,
Her skin is extremely soft and tender, her adornments are extremely special,
His majestic appearance is delightful, shining like a golden mountain.
At that time, the upÄsakas, loving his appearance, became confused in mind and intention.
At that time, the attendants of the courtesan, seeing this, deeply rejoiced and said with a laugh:

At that time, the Dharma teacher wondered why the four assemblies were agitated and changed from usual, so he raised his eyebrows with his hand and looked around the assembly. He saw that the courtesan had a dignified appearance, and her attendants were all adorned. The courtesan was in the middle, as bright as a star, stealing the foolish people's minds and causing them to lose their right mindfulness.
At that time, the Dharma teacher observed the woman's intention, wondering what she had come here for.
He then silently entered concentration and knew that her deception was not for listening to the Dharma.
Although this Dharma teacher had already eliminated anger, he outwardly displayed an angry expression and spoke loudly to the courtesan, saying:

You are like an anthill, wanting to compare its height with Mount Sumeru. Have you not heard that in the past, when the Buddha was in the world, the sixth heavenly king, without measuring his own strength, dared to create disturbances in the presence of the Buddha? The World-Honored One's spiritual power then used a corpse to tie around his neck, causing him to be ashamed and ridiculed by humans and gods?
Do you think that the Buddha's teachings have been destroyed?
Are there no diligent Å›rÄvakas?
Have all the superior men completely disappeared?
If this is so, you should firmly uphold yourself.

At that time, the Dharma teacher then used his spiritual powers to transform the prostitute, causing her skin and flesh to fall off, leaving only white bones, with all her internal organs exposed. He then called out to the prostitute in front of the assembly:
You have given rise to evil thoughts and dared to dispute with the Buddha's teachings.
At that time, the prostitute stood before the assembly with her skeletal body.
At that time, the Dharma teacher then spoke a verse, saying:
You used to be attracted to beautiful forms,
Now your flesh and skin are all gone, leaving only an empty skeleton.ğŸ”½You used to delight in fair skin,
Now you finally see the true nature of things.
The skull is like a white shell, the shape and color like lotus roots,
The eye sockets are sunken, the two cheeks like deep ditches,
The mechanisms have all come apart, the tendons and veins are roughly connected,
The internal organs and so forth are suspended in the air, exposed.
Those who follow you see this and give rise to disgust,
How much more so the other great assemblies,
Who will delight in seeing it?

At that time, the skeleton, having transformed its form for the Dharma teacher, with both body and mind exhausted, unable to straighten itself, crossed its skeletal hands and faced the Dharma teacher.
At that time, the Dharma teacher said to the skeleton:
Your complexion, ornaments, and various adornments only deceive ordinary people, causing them to become deeply attached and sink into the pool of the three realms of existence.
If you can now remove your coquettishness and discard your ornaments, I will show you the body of tranquil purity, allowing you to know the impure market.

This body is covered with thin flesh on the outside, filled with filth and evil, and externally relies on grease and powder to deceive the eyes of the foolish. Ordinary people are infatuated and blinded by desire, thus giving rise to attachment.
What wise person, after carefully observing it, would cherish and play with it?
At that time, those in the assembly, having witnessed this, all gave rise to disgust and each said to the other:
The teachings spoken by the World-Honored One are true and not false. All dharmas are like illusions, like transformations, like bubbles in water, like gold-plated coins, only deceiving people.

The woman's beautiful appearance and demeanor that were so captivating have suddenly now become a mere heap of bones. The graceful poses and seductive expressions, like the work of a witch, where have they gone now?
A lay devotee, supporting his chin with his hand, contemplated the woman and spoke a verse, saying:
The Sage says that sentient beings are blinded by desire and love.
Because they are blind without the eyes of wisdom, they cannot proceed to nirvana.
Like a leaf of the nimba tree, smeared with honey, eaten by insects,
they are deluded by greed, not abandoning it even unto death.
Those who are heedful, contemplating the characteristics of the body in truth,
do not give rise to lustful thoughts, like the king of white cranes,
always dwelling in a clear pool, not delighting in a charnel ground.
Another lay devotee said this:
Seeing this appearance, lustful thoughts arise. Observing their white bones, they are immediately eliminated.
And spoke this verse:ğŸ”½Observing that pile of bones,
It can give rise to fear in people,
Like a vidyÄdhara's magical device,
Fools take it to be real, and give rise to a mind of attachment.
Like a deep pit on the road, covered with grass on top,ğŸ”½This body is also like this,
One should contemplate in this way.
Having truly understood this, who would give rise to lustful thoughts?
At that time, the deluded, attached, foolish, and ignorant ones, having heard this verse, lowered their heads and avoided it, and in the end did not enjoy hearing it.
At that time, the woman herself saw that her body was despised by others, and threw herself to the ground, then spoke this verse:
Previously I was foolish and ignorant, not measuring my own strength,
I wish to turn back the assembly listening to the Dharma, all of you should return home.
Only now do I realize that the ÅšÄkyas have extremely extraordinary power,
They have transformed my wonderful appearance, causing those who see it to give rise to disgust.
I am like a foolish child, my actions are extremely frivolous,
I dare to compare the water in a cow's hoofprint to the great ocean.
I only pray that you will take pity on me and allow me to repent with sincere heart.
At that time, the great assembly saw that the woman's bones were propped up like a reed hut, and they were greatly astonished. How could such a collection of bones speak like this?

Moreover, they saw that all her internal organs were exposed, like the internal organs hanging in a butcher's shop, wriggling and moving like dog meat, and the stench of the organs was worse than a latrine.
How could we see such a thing?
They then spoke a verse, saying:
Now observing the woman's body, only sinews connect the withered bones,
Only seeing an empty collection of bones, yet it can speak with a unified voice.
Are there bones within the woman?
Are there women within the bones?
It is like in a vast marsh, a grove of reeds,
Blowing together in the wind, producing a great sound.
Thus, due to false dharmas, the body of a woman is not seen.
If there is no self-body, where is the appearance of a woman?
Thoroughly investigating all dharmas, never before has there been.
I carefully observe the body's appearance, coming and going, and advancing and stopping,
Bending and stretching, bowing and raising the head, looking around and speaking,
The joints supporting each other, the ribs very sparse,
Bound by sinews, forming a mechanism, relying on it to move and turn.
In this way, in each and every one, there is no master at all,
And now, are these dharmas existent or nonexistent?
Am I deluded by madness and foolishness, or by a dull and disordered vision?
How can one give rise to the false notion of a woman in such a place?
Binding reeds to make a machine, using many strings and threads,
It is like molten true gold, pouring water and then making a sound.
At that time, the Dharma teacher knew that the four assemblies had all given rise to disgust, and said to the prostitute:
What do you wish to do now?
The woman said to the Dharma teacher:
Do you wish to abandon the house?
Then she spoke a verse, saying:
The house of the great-headed sage,
Transforming the heavenly maiden Lanba, causing her to become a grass horse, for a full twelve years.
Do you now make a house?
Causing me to become a cemetery, the world has never seen such a house?
The greatly virtuous one, out of compassion for me, wishes to remove it.
At that time, the Dharma teacher then smiled and spoke a verse, saying:
Good woman, you may rise, I have no angry thoughts,
Shaving the head and wearing the monastic robe, I will never abandon the Dharma.
If there is desire and attachment to that, harming others gives rise to suffering,
If one does good or evil, one is then able to give rise to anger.
Does anger make a house?
I have extinguished the bonds of anger, cut off ignorance, and my essence is free from bonds.
If I wish to save sentient beings, how could I make a house?
Sentient beings are tormented by the suffering of birth, old age, sickness, and death.
How could a wise person
make a house?
Like a foul and poisonous sore, further covered with caustic ash,
A thin skin covers the mechanism, the foolish and ignorant give rise to attachment and delusion,ğŸ”½I will use my supernormal powers
to open your impure chest.
Having spoken this verse, he retracted his supernormal powers, and the woman returned to her original form.
At that time, the Dharma teacher said to the assembly:
You should diligently cultivate goodness.
Then he spoke a verse, saying:
The inverted thoughts of desire are like wind stirring up dust,
But the face of right contemplation free from desire washes away the dust of desire.
The presence of desire and freedom from desire are not necessarily fixed,
But through good contemplation, one attains liberation. Attachment to delusion increases desire.
Therefore, one should always cultivate and diligently give rise to the thought of freedom from desire,
For freedom from desire is the tranquility of all goodness, and one attains the bliss of meditation.
At that time, the assembly listening to the Dharma, some attained the contemplation of impurity,
Some attained the fruit of stream-entry, and in the cultivation of the thought of freedom from desire,
Some attained the fruit of non-return, and there were also those who went forth,
Diligent in practice without laziness, and attained arhatship.
21 (21) Furthermore, if one gives everything without attachment, one will gain great fame and receive rewards in this life. Therefore, one should give without being stingy or attached.

I once heard that in the country of Bukongwei, there was a painter named Jiena. He had a reason to go to Shizhuguo. After arriving there, he went to various stupas and temples. He painted a monastery and received thirty taels of gold.
When he returned to his home country, he happened to encounter people holding a ganachakra feast. With a feeling of faith and respect, he asked the attending monk:
Who will prepare the food tomorrow?
The monk replied:
There is no one to prepare it.
He further asked:
How much does it cost to prepare a meal for that monk for one day?
The monk replied:
It costs thirty taels of gold.
The painter then gave the attending monk thirty taels of gold.
After giving the gold, he returned home. His wife asked:
What have you earned as a guest worker?
The husband replied to his wife:
I earned thirty taels of gold to use for the merit assembly.

When his wife heard this, she became very angry and told her relatives about her husband's faults, saying that all the gold he earned was used for the assembly and none was left to support the family.
At that time, the relatives took him to the magistrate and said:
The money and wealth earned through hard work is not used to support the family or relatives, but is all used to organize various merit assemblies.
When the magistrate heard this, he asked the man:
Is it really so?
He replied:
It is true.
When the magistrate heard this, he had a rare thought and immediately praised him, saying:
Excellent, good man!
He took off his own clothes, necklaces, and horse, and gave them all to the painter, speaking a verse, saying:
Having long suffered in poverty, I earned money by working,
Not using it for my livelihood, it is difficult to give in charity.
Although I have wealth and riches, and my livelihood is extremely abundant,
If I do not observe well, I cannot quickly give in charity.
Observing far into future lives, knowing that giving has its rewards,
Daring to let go of wealth, free from the dust and defilements of stinginess,
If there are people who practice like this, upholding giving and preventing it from sinking.
When the painter heard this verse, he was overjoyed, put on the clothes, rode the horse, and returned home.

At that time, the painter's family saw him wearing fine clothes and riding a horse to the gate, thinking he was a noble person, and their hearts were filled with fear, so they closed the door and hid.
The painter said:
I am not someone else, I am your husband.
His wife said:
You are a poor man, where did you get this horse and carriage?
At that time, the husband replied in verse:
Good woman, listen now, I will tell you the truth,
Although I have given to the Sangha now, the food has not yet been served,
It is like a sprout growing even before the seed is planted,
The field of merit is extremely fertile, the karmic reward is still to come.
This pure field of merit for the Sangha, who would not plant in it?
When I am about to plant the seed, the sprout grows and is seen by all.
When the wife heard this, she attained pure faith and spoke a verse, saying:
As the Buddha has said, giving to the Sangha brings great fruit,
Now, in this giving, one truly finds the place to give.
With a respectful mind, giving a little water, the karmic reward surpasses the great ocean,
Among all the assemblies, the Buddha and the Sangha are the foremost.
When you open your mind and wish to give, the flowers should already be in front of you.
Furthermore, the practice of giving is based on supreme faith, and the rewards of giving even two coins are immeasurable.
I once heard that a woman went to Dayan Mountain and saw many people there performing a gancha puja.
At that time, the woman begged for food at the assembly. Seeing the monks, she was filled with joy and praised them, saying:
Excellent, holy Sangha!
Just like the great ocean, a treasure trove, worshipped by many people;
I alone am poor and have nothing to give.
Having said this, she searched all over her body but found nothing. She then thought to herself:
I once found two copper coins in the garbage.
She then took the coins and offered them to the Sangha.

At that time, the senior monk had attained the fruit of arhatship and could foresee people's thoughts. Although the senior monk always cherished himself, he saw that the woman had deep faith and, in order to increase her merit, he did not wait for the vihÄra but personally arose with sincerity to chant the vow, raising his right hand and loudly proclaiming:
Venerable monks, listen!
He then spoke a verse, saying:
The great earth and the great ocean, all the treasures therein,
To the extent of this young woman's intention, she can give them all to the Saá¹…gha.
Keep your mind focused on observing well, practice the path to cultivate merit,
And attain the path of liberation, leaving behind the thorns of poverty.

At that time, the young woman gave rise to a great mind. As the teacher said, I will do what is difficult to do. She immediately gave up all her wealth and precious treasures without any difference. With a mixture of sadness and joy, she prostrated herself on the ground and took refuge in the Sangha. She placed the two coins in front of the senior monk, wept with grief, and immediately spoke a verse, saying:
I wish that throughout birth and death, I will forever be free from poverty,
And always experience the gathering of joy and celebration, with relatives never separated.
I now offer fruits to the Sangha, only the Buddha can discern this,
By the merit of this, may I quickly accomplish the fruits of my wishes,
And by the slightly wholesome mind I have planted, may my body's faculties quickly emerge.
At that time, after the woman left the mountain, she sat under a tree. The shade of the tree did not move, and there was a cloud canopy above.

At that time, the king of that country had just lost his wife and was out wandering when he saw the cloud canopy going to the tree. Seeing this young girl, he gave rise to lustful attachment and took her back to the palace to be his first and greatest queen.
He then had this thought:
I have already fulfilled my vow.
He then said to the king:
Take many precious things and set up offerings, go to Dayan Mountain to make offerings to the Sangha, with jeweled necklaces and various wealth, and use them to make offerings.
At that time, the senior monk did not chant a blessing.
At that time, the great assembly suspected the reason and said this:
Previously, when she was poor and gave two coins, he chanted a blessing for her;
Now, she is the king's queen, and uses precious jewels, necklaces, and various wealth to make offerings, but he does not chant a blessing?
At that time, the senior monk said to the Sangha:
When I previously made a wish for them, it was not for the sake of wealth, but rather because I feared that the young girl's mind might become confused, so I made a wish.
He then spoke a verse, saying:
It is not by having much money and wealth that one obtains great rewards,
Only by having a superior and wholesome mind can one obtain great rewards.
When that girl made a donation in the past, she gave up everything,
The Buddha's wisdom can discern this, it is not something I can know.
Even though one may now have much wealth and treasure, it is not as good as the mind of that time,
One sixteenth of it.
It is like merchants who have little wealth,
But their minds hope for great rewards.
The mind is superior and vast, therefore in the future,
The rewards obtained will also be immeasurable.
Using the earth with a pure mind to make a donation is also like in the city of ÅšrÄvastÄ«,
The poor and lowly woman who offered rice gruel to KÄÅ›yapa.
By giving earth, one obtains the great earth; by giving food and drink, one attains the supreme in the heavens.
Giving little with a pure mind brings vast rewards, and one's attainments are also vast.
Just as a white and pure garment, when a drop of oil is applied to it,
the stains and grease increase and grow, just as if it were an oil drop in water.
Although the oil drop is small, it spreads over the surface of the pond,
Therefore, one should know that because the mind is superior, the rewards are great.
